content: All poultry (breasts, whole bird, legs, thighs, wings, ground poultry) must be cooked to 165°F (74°C).
Ground beef, pork, veal, and lamb must be cooked to 160°F (71°C).
Steaks, chops, and roasts (beef, pork, veal, lamb) must reach 145°F (63°C) and rest for 3 minutes.
Fish must be cooked to 145°F (63°C) or until flesh is opaque and separates easily.
Cook eggs until yolk and white are firm. Egg dishes must reach 160°F (71°C).
All leftovers and casseroles must be reheated to an internal temperature of 165°F (74°C).
Bacteria grow rapidly between 40°F and 140°F. Never leave food in this range for more than 2 hours (1 hour if above 90°F).
Cooked rice is prone to Bacillus cereus. Refrigerate within 1 hour and keep for max 3-4 days.
Foods containing mayonnaise, cream, or dairy that have been left out for more than 2 hours must be discarded.
Raw poultry should only be kept in the fridge for 1-2 days. Freeze it if you won't use it by then.
Raw steaks, roasts, and chops can be kept in the fridge for 3-5 days.
Raw ground meat (beef, turkey, veal, pork) keeps in the fridge for only 1-2 days.
Raw eggs in shell keep for 3-5 weeks. Hard-boiled eggs keep for 1 week.
NEVER thaw perishable foods on the counter. The outside warms up while the inside is frozen, inviting bacteria.
Thaw in leak-proof bag submerged in cold water. Change water every 30 minutes. Cook immediately after thawing.
Do NOT wash raw poultry or meat. It spreads bacteria to sink and counters via splashing.
Use separate cutting boards for produce and raw meat. Wash hands/tools with hot soapy water after touching raw meat.
Homemade garlic-in-oil mixtures must be refrigerated and used within 7 days. Left at room temp, they can cause fatal botulism.
Never use food from cans that are leaking, bulging, rusting, or badly dented. This may indicate botulism.
Baked potatoes wrapped in foil must be kept hot (above 140°F) or refrigerated immediately. Do not leave them at room temp in foil.
Eating raw oysters puts you at risk for Vibrio bacteria. Cook shellfish until shells open; discard any that don't open.
Unpasteurized (raw) milk can carry Salmonella, E. coli, and Listeria. It is especially dangerous for children and pregnant women.
Pregnant women should avoid raw fish (sushi), unpasteurized cheese (brie, feta), and deli meats (unless heated to steaming) due to Listeria.
Do not give honey to children under 1 year. It can contain botulism spores their immune systems cannot fight.
Wash hands with soap and warm water for 20 seconds before cooking and after handling raw meat or eggs.
Food frozen at 0°F remains safe indefinitely, but quality/texture degrades after 3-12 months depending on the item.
Do not heat oils beyond their smoke point (e.g., Extra Virgin Olive Oil ~375°F). Overheated oil releases carcinogens.
NEVER use water on a grease fire. Smother with a metal lid or baking soda, or use a Class B extinguisher.
Never mix bleach with ammonia or vinegar. It creates deadly chlorine gas.
If mold appears on soft food (bread, yogurt, soft cheese, soft fruit), discard the entire item. Roots may go deep.
If mold appears on hard cheese, cut off at least 1 inch around and below the mold spot. The rest is safe.
Never reuse marinade used on raw meat as a sauce unless you boil it first to kill bacteria.
Color is NOT a reliable indicator of doneness (especially for burgers). Always use a meat thermometer.
Refrigerate pasta sauce, salsa, and condiments after opening. Check label for 'Refrigerate After Opening'.
Low-acid foods (vegetables, meats) must be canned using a pressure canner to prevent botulism.
High-acid foods (fruits, pickles, tomatoes) can be safely canned in a boiling water bath.
Cool leftovers quickly by dividing into small shallow containers. Refrigerate within 2 hours (1 hour if above 90°F).
Reheat leftovers to an internal temperature of 165°F before consuming.
Cook stuffing separately from poultry to ensure it reaches a safe temperature of 165°F.
Potato and egg salads must be kept refrigerated and consumed within 3-5 days.
Consume sushi from reputable sources that follow proper freezing protocols to kill parasites.
Always read labels for potential allergens, especially when trying new products.
Sanitize cutting boards and utensils after use with raw meat using a solution of 1 tablespoon bleach per gallon of water.
Stay informed about food recalls from reliable sources to avoid consuming contaminated products.
